724916f-a.title: Manhattan: York Avenue - 89th Street
724916f-a.text:
York Ave., at the N.E. corner of East 89th Street. Also shown is
East 89th Street, north side, east from and including York Ave., to the East
R iver. Buildings shown form a portion of the House of the Good Shepherd.
January 31, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

724917f-b.title: Manhattan: York Avenue - 89th Street
724917f-b.text:
(1)
York avenue (Avenue A), east side, from 89th to 91st Streets,
showing, on the northeast corner of 89th Street, one of the
buildings of the House of the Good Shepherd, ''a house of
Iefuge for fallen women and girls, who desire to reform'
(King's Handbook of New York City, 1892). Other buildings of
the House of the Good Shepherd are farther east in the same
block.
The House of the Good Shepherd was founded in 1857; this build-
ing on the N.E. corner of BVth Street, which used to belong
to St. Ann's Home, was built aound 1665.
St. Ann's Home for Destitute Children, founded in 1879, occu3ies
the S.E. corner of 90th Street. The whole block, at the time
of this picture, is about to be razed. In the block from 91st
to 92nd Streets may be seen the new garage of the Municipal
Asphalt Plant.
January 3l, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(2)
The same, six years later, showing the playground on the site of
the demolished buildings f om 8Vth to 90th Streets.
October 9, 1934.
L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

724918f-a.title: Manhattan: York Avenue - 89th Street
724918f-a.text:
york Avenue, west side, from 89th to 91st Streets, with clearing on
east side from 8Vth to 90th Streets.
The block from 89th to 90th Streets was occupied till about 1918
by St. Joseph's Orphan Asylum, an institution for German Children,
incorporated in 1859. The cigar factory on the S.Wi. corner of 90th
Street used to be one of the Orphan Aeylum buildings, erected in
the early 1880's.
1731-33-35 York Avenue (formerly Avenue A), at and adjoining the N.W.
corner of 90th Street, antedate 1891; 1791 on the corner is a frame
house. The 5-story buildings, above them, to the corner of 91st
Street, were not built till around 1895.
March 29, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
